channel.title: math.AT updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: math.AT updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: A net theoretic approach to homotopy theory
item.description: arXiv:2410.18245v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper uses a net-theoretic approach to convergence spaces, aimed to simplify the description of continuous convergence in order to apply it in problems concerning Homotopy Theory. We present methods for handling homotopies of limit spaces, define fundamental groupoids, and prove a generalized version of the Seifert-van Kampen Theorem for limit spaces.
item.dc:creator: Renan Maneli Mezabarba, Rodrigo Santos Monteiro, Thales Fernando Vilamaior Paiva

item.title: Unstable homotopy groups and Lie algebras
item.description: arXiv:2410.18330v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We survey the role of Lie algebras in the study of unstable homotopy groups.
item.dc:creator: Mark Behrens, Connor Malin

item.title: An eigenring construction for free groups and free modules
item.description: arXiv:2410.18877v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Let $k$ be a commutative unital ring. For a $k$-algebra $A$ with a multiplicative submodule $J$, we have a canonical subquotient algebra $\mathrm{E}_{A}(J)$ called the eigenring. In the case where $J$ is a left ideal, an adjunction exists between the category of $A$-modules and that of $\mathrm{E}_{A}(J)$-modules. The derived functors associated with this adjunction recover several well-known homological invariants, including group (co)homology and Hochschild (co)homology. The purpose of this paper is to present an extension of these constructions, where $k$-algebras are replaced with monads within a specified bicategory. This approach may be regarded as a categorification of eigenrings, given that monads in the bicategory are equivalent with $k$-linear categories. Furthermore, we generalize the aforementioned adjunction, demonstrating how the associated derived functors provide examples of functor homology. For a category $\mathcal{C}$, a module over $\mathcal{C}$ is defined as a functor from $\mathcal{C}$ to the category of $k$-modules and $k$-linear maps. In the case where $\mathcal{C}$ is either the opposite category of free groups or that of free modules over a ring $R$, specific types of modules over $\mathcal{C}$ naturally emerge within the context of algebraic topology. These include polynomial modules, analytic modules, outer modules and primitively generated modules. The majority of this paper is devoted to applying the general framework to the study of these module types. The categorification of eigenrings leads to a unified framework in which these types are characterized by certain internal data of the monad $\mathtt{L}_{\mathcal{C}}$ associated with $\mathcal{C}$. In applications, we obtain calculations of particular functor homologies and uncover new aspects of the above module types.
item.dc:creator: Minkyu Kim

item.title: Fan distributions via Tverberg partitions and Gale duality
item.description: arXiv:2410.18331v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Equipartition theory, beginning with the classical ham sandwich theorem, seeks the fair division of finite point sets in $\mathbb{R}^d$ by full-dimensional regions determined by a prescribed geometric dissection of $\mathbb{R}^d$. Here we examine \emph{equidistributions} of finite point sets in $\mathbb{R}^d$ by prescribed \emph{low dimensional} subsets. Our main result states that if $r\geq 3$ is a prime power, then for any $m$-coloring of a sufficiently small point set $X$ in $\mathbb{R}^d$ there exists a certain type of $r$-fan in $\mathbb{R}^d$ -- namely, the union of $r$ ``half-flats'' of codimension $r-2$ centered about a common $(r-1)$-codimensional affine subspace -- which captures all the points of $X$ in such a way that each half-flat contains at most an $r$-th of the points from each color class. The number of points in $\mathbb{R}^d$ we require for this is essentially tight when $m\geq 2$, and for typical point sets the \emph{interiors} of the half-flats must share a robust fraction of the points of $X$. We also give analogous equidistribution results for small point sets in $\mathbb{C}^d$ by regular $r$-fans which are centered about a complex hyperplane. In the same way that a theorem of Dolnikov on hyperplane piercings generalizes the ham sandwich theorem, our equidistribution results extend to ``piercing distributions'' for families of subsets of $X$ satisfying particular intersection criteria. Our proof method continues recent work of Frick et al., where the Gale transform was shown to link Dolnikov-type hyperplane transversals and Radon-type partitions. Similarly, our results arise as the real and complex Gale duals of linear versions of Tverberg-type theorems. Finally, we extend our distribution results to multiple $r$-fans after establishing a multiple intersection version of a topological Tverberg-type theorem due to Sarkaria.
item.dc:creator: Shuai Huang, Japser Miller, Daniel Rose-Levine, Steven Simon

item.title: Perfect even modules and the even filtration
item.description: arXiv:2304.04685v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Inspired by the work of Hahn-Raksit-Wilson, we introduce a variant of the even filtration which is naturally defined on $\mathbf{E}_{1}$-rings and their modules. We show that our variant satisfies flat descent and so agrees with the Hahn-Raksit-Wilson filtration on ring spectra of arithmetic interest, showing that various "motivic" filtrations are in fact invariants of the $\mathbf{E}_{1}$-structure alone. We prove that our filtration can be calculated via appropriate resolutions in modules and apply it to the study of even cohomology of connective $\mathbf{E}_{1}$-rings, proving vanishing above the Milnor line, base-change formulas, and explicitly calculating cohomology in low weights.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Pstr\k{a}gowski

item.title: Operators on symmetric polynomials and applications in computing the cohomology of $BPU_n$
item.description: arXiv:2410.11691v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: This paper studies the integral cohomology ring of the classifying space $BPU_n$ of the projective unitary group $PU_n$. By calculating a Serre spectral sequence, we determine the ring stucture of $H^*(BPU_n;\mathbb{Z})$ in dimensions $\leq 11$. For any odd prime $p$, we also determine the $p$-primary subgroups of $H^i(BPU_n;\mathbb{Z})$ in the range $i\leq 2p+13$ for $i$ odd and $i\leq 4p+8$ for $i$ even. The main technique used in the calculation is applying the theory of Young diagrams and Schur polynomials to certain linear operators on symmetric polynomials.
item.dc:creator: Feifei Fan

item.title: Unexpected loss of maximality: the case of Hilbert square of real surfaces
item.description: arXiv:2303.02796v3 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: We explore the maximality of the Hilbert square of maximal real surfaces, and find that in many cases the Hilbert square is maximal if and only if the surface has connected real locus. In particular, the Hilbert square of no maximal K3-surface is maximal. Nevertheless, we exhibit maximal surfaces with disconnected real locus whose Hilbert square is maximal.
item.dc:creator: Viatcheslav Kharlamov, Rare\c{s} R\u{a}sdeaconu

item.title: The Serre spectral sequence of a Lie subalgebroid
item.description: arXiv:2405.00419v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: We study a spectral sequence approximating Lie algebroid cohomology associated to a Lie subalgebroid. This is a simultaneous generalisation of several classical constructions in differential geometry, including the Leray-Serre spectral sequence for de Rham cohomology associated to a fibration, the Hochschild-Serre spectral sequence for Lie algebras, and the Mackenzie spectral sequence for Lie algebroid extensions. We show that, for wide Lie subalgebroids, the spectral sequence converges to the Lie algebroid cohomology, and that, for Lie subalgebroids over proper submanifolds, the spectral sequence converges to the formal Lie algebroid cohomology. We discuss applications and recover several constructions in Poisson geometry in which this spectral sequence has appeared naturally in the literature.
item.dc:creator: Ioan M\u{a}rcu\c{t}, Andreas Sch\"u{\ss}ler
